title: CTRL0000916072 - Transcribed Interview of Matthew Clarke (Aug. 4, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 10:13 a.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is the transcribed interview of Matthew Clarke
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
U.S. Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your last
My name is Matthew Todd Clarke, last name C-1-a-r-k-e.
Now, Mr. Clarke, this will be a staff-led interview,
although members may choose to ask questions.
senior investigative counsel; on my right,
and I am an investigative counsel with the
With me from the select committee is
, another financial investigator, on the Webex.
I will note that we are currently joined
Now, Mr. Clarke, you are voluntarily here for this
I'll just tell you some background rules.
There are official reporters transcribing the record of the interview, and that
transcription will be the official record of the proceeding.
and video recorded, and we ask that you not record it yourself.
Please wait until each question is completed before you begin to respond, and
we'll do our best to wait until your response is complete before we ask the next question.
The reporters cannot note nonverbal responses, such as shaking or nodding your
head, so it's important that you respond to each question with an audible verbal
Please give complete answers to the best of your recollection.
is unclear, please ask for clarification.
If you do not know the answer, please just say so.
And as we remind everyone we interview, it's unlawful to deliberately provide
false information to Congress, and doing so may result in penalties.
At any time if you would like to take a break or otherwise for any reason, just let
And before we begin, do you have any questions?
Now, Mr. Clarke, before we get started, do you remember meeting with us
or at least speaking with myself and
a few weeks back in a phone call?
Today's interview is going to look very similar to that informal interview, and
we're going to go through many of the same topics that we discussed then.
But to the extent that we're covering the same topics, please still provide fulsome
answers here so we can have a complete record in this interview.
Can you please provide your date of birth?
I reside in East Grand Rapids, Michigan.
And what is your cell phone number?
And is that a number you use both for business and in your personal life?
And do you use any other email addresses?
I have other business email address and personal email address.
I use them for what, like for my life?
Well, just how many other email addresses do you have?
I mean, I have a Gmail account.
And then I have, as we had
discussed, I have other business interests and companies unrelated.
email address that I would operate on for anything that had to do with this.
And tell us a bit about your educational background.
My education is I went to undergrad marketing
degree and then law school at Marshall in Ohio.
And am an attorney by, I guess, trade
and training, although most days I think I'm a sales guy and a consultant and a tech guy
and all those kinds of things.
Let's go briefly through your professional background.
What years were you at the Maricopa County Attorney's Office?
I have a cough drop in my mouth.
So if you can't understand something I say, I'll try to enunciate with this
I think that was probably -- I worked for a small
civil litigation firm for a period of time, like less than a year maybe.
And then I joined the Maricopa County Attorney's Office I think in '98, '97 or -- '98,
and I was there for a couple years.
I was a prosecutor in that office, tried lots of cases.
Then I moved to civil litigation.
I joined a firm that was in Phoenix.
regional firm, small, called Ryley Carlock Applewhite.
by another firm or folded into another firm or something.
That firm has since been acquired
You want the -- sort of the whole --
I'm trying to answer the questions you ask me so I don't go off on these
rambling tangents, so please just direct me.
So my understanding is that at Ryley Carlock you were the co-founder of the firm's
And we were essentially almost like a legal services and legal process outsource company.
So the idea was with DCG, if you went to a law firm and hired them to do
something, they would have paralegals at $150 to $250 an hour and associates at $300 an
hour on up doing all of this bottom-of-the-pyramid work.
you built a different model that was not a traditional law firm model you could make
those lawyers available at significantly discounted rates.
So when I was in the Litigation Group, we started a little
It was actually inside the Litigation Practice Group.
And we had this idea that if
So we built this little division of the practice group and we called it DCG, and it was
This was paper discovery when we built it, but it
wasn't long after we launched that that 2006 rolled around and all the changes on the
eDiscovery rules and the Zubulake case that changed the world, and it became sort of the
And we very quickly spun that group into an eDiscovery group and technology
And I was with that -- I was with Ryley with DCG until 2016, and at that point we
wanted to expand DCG more globally.
We then and now were representing some of the largest corporations in the
world, and we couldn't have a little Arizona footprint.
We needed to have a global
So we had several offices around the country, but we needed to have presence in
Europe and we needed to have an outsource solution that was comparable to the India
model, and we looked at South Africa for that.
And the firm that we were with, it was bigger than them.
It was too much for them.
So we left and we started a new group.
We joined a different law firm and
started a new group that we called SBS, and it was that same model.
And that group -- we did that in August 2016, something like that.
still -- a hundred and some attorneys working for that group doing primarily manage
review, anything that would be in the litigation pyramid or below the litigation pyramid,
timelines, witness binders, factory search, deposition binders, all that kind of stuff.
We were built as sort of a legal outsource.
So a fraction of the cost of a
traditional law firm model, but still operating out of a law firm kind of.
And then we were able to secure a presence in Europe and South Africa.
got that international thing that we were looking for.
And then we brought on technology and we became a full EDRM end-to-end
So everything forensics, collection processing, hosting, review, right on
And at some point -- and I'm going to keep going, just give the history of this.
So at some point we -- every now and then we would end up
attorney would seize computers and someone would need to do a pre-review, a taint
Maybe we'd be brought in as a taint team.
So we kind of ended up in some situations where we were working for the
agencies default to the Big Four, the big players in that space.
as them for sure, in my opinion, and we had all talent and skill and know-how to do it.
And we were, I thought, markedly less expensive.
Gosh, there's a huge opportunity in the
And we knew a lot of the times, I think, maybe government
So we started the process of trying to get some -- there are different ways that
you can get approval to do government contracts.
SAM approval, which we ended up getting in maybe the middle of 2020.
point, we were pretty focused on trying to break into some government contracts and try
In 2019, I think, we started to get
Now, all the while there's this voice in my head that's saying:
representing some of the largest corporations in the world that tend to be on the other
side of the V, the DOJ or the SEC or the FTC.
Is that going to create potential conflicts
And so we started having a conversation about spinning up a different company.
We knew how to do it.
And we thought maybe having a different
company, so that if we ended up in a situation where we had conflicts we could just
simply break them apart and it wouldn't impact SBS, which was our core company.
And then this opportunity sort of started to show itself in early 2021.
We knew there was a lot of stuff going on.
Then we saw the -- we're always watching to see what opportunities exist.
sure we over the years have thrown every arrow that we could at potential opportunities,
just trying to get a meeting, trying to get a sit, like just typical sales guys.
And so we saw this opportunity.
I think it was like -- maybe it was like
February --1 don't remember exactly when the COVID -- the committee on the COVID
started asking for documents related -- from NARA -- related to the prior administration.
But about that time we made some inquiries and got a meeting and were able to
get hired by MAGA, or I don't remember what the entity was, to help support the former
administration's review of NARA documents that had to be turned over to whatever that
If I could interrupt you there, Mr. Clarke.
So when you say SBS, that's Strategic Business Solutions.
And when you created 2M Document Management and Imaging, LLC, that's
So SBS is Strategic Business Solutions, that's correct.
So when you created 2M, did you already have a contract or otherwise work that
And we'll refer to that as 2M.
you had secured for that company, or did the creation precede the securing of the work
I'm pretty sure that it preceded it, because if we were going to pursue it
heavily we didn't want to pursue it as SBS.
government contracts and we thought this was a viable opportunity for us, we created
So when we decided to really heavily pursue
When you say "this" was a viable opportunity for us, I just want to make sure
that we're very clear about what the "this" is.
I think the first -- the first thing that -- how we ended up in this was the
former administration was responding to -- there were requests that were made from the
House Oversight Committee, I guess, on COVID, or the White House response to COVID,
that they were getting from NARA, as you know.
And then the former administration had the opportunity to review those
documents to assert executive and other privileges to them.
thought there was an opportunity for us to help with that.
I mean, the decision ultimately wasn't ours, but we could help host and hold that
the ultimate decisionmakers on making those decisions.
And we knew that we could help organize and sort and filter and pre-tag to help
And just to be clear, only because we're using terms that some people may
not understand, but when you say the former administration, you're speaking about
President Trump's former administration as President?
So when requests were made of the former Presidential administration, this
is the opportunity that we're discussing.
And -- actually, I don't want to get off track.
Mr. Clarke, just to clarify, I think previously you talked
about a private relationship with Eric Herschmann that provided an introduction to this
Can you kind of clarify, just give us a timeline of how Mr. Herschmann facilitated
you getting involved with reviewing the administration's documents?
We were looking -- again, we always -- we're always looking at everything.
I don't know that I would characterize it as him facilitating it.
And at some point we noted that the Kasowitz firm was involved
I didn't know precisely what the involvement was.
I just knew that you'd see
And then Eric Herschmann showed up at the hearings or
We had worked with him 25 years ago on a matter.
So that to us was a point of entry.
So I think we reached -- I don't remember exactly how it went.
reached out to Eric and said:
some big player to do all this data hosting.
Why don't you -- can we have a meeting
Hey, you guys, I think, probably are looking at Deloitte or
And Eric was open to the idea.
I don't think it really made a tremendous amount
I do recall him being pretty clear that it would be -- he thought it
could be challenging to deal with NARA, because he thought NARA could very quickly, I
don't want to say be over its skis because I think they're very talented, but there was an
enormous amount of data that was probably being requested from them and they had
So I just remember him saying:
Well, look, we can have this conversation about
you guys coming on, but you're going to have to understand there's going to have to be a
lot of perhaps hand-holding and helping on the NARA side just to make sure that
there -- because we want this to be seamless.
And it ended up being true.
Basically was the communication to us.
I mean, we totally get it.
Again, terrific people at NARA, work very hard, but
they were -- we could tell from the very beginning when we started getting data from
them that it was complicated for them.
An example would be they might give us 5,000 pages, and there was no LED.
There was no logical -- there might be 5,000 single-page TIFF images and it might be a
seven-page document, and page 2 might not necessarily be next to page 1.
And so there was a lot of scattered information.
So we just worked with NARA to talk about paths to better sort and provide data.
And then when they brought in Relativity, of course, that was probably a huge challenge
time, so we knew what to do.
That's a complicated system to operate.
We'd been operating it for a long
And we were supportive of them, I think, in that, in their implementation role.
We offered to help, that kind of stuff.
So that's sort of an aside, but --
There was a lot in there.
When do you think the relationship with Mr. -- the discussions
When did the -- it was maybe within a month of when we were retained.
I'm going to say maybe it was February of '21.
So it would have been relatively close to that.
I think we got hired in April or May of
And then he set a meeting.
We might have made two pitches.
Yeah, okay, we'll give you guys a shot on this.
So we got hired to do the data hosting.
And there's a lot of different parts that
go with that on the review side, consulting side, organizational side, tech sides.
I think we're going to cover the sides.
I just want to ask you, who was
present for the pitches that you discussed in addition to Mr. Herschmann?
They were telephonic, so I wouldn't have known.
law firm, and I always get this guy's name wrong.

And there was an Alex Cannon.
And I don't -- honestly, I don't remember whether Eric was even on that call.
might have just gave our -- he might have made an introduction and then we reached out.
I think we -- I don't want to speculate or guess.
I think there were a couple of
But honestly, it's not that memorable to me in terms of what time it was

Okay, like how would you do it?
one thing to say you can do it, but now tell me how you're going to do it.
And then at some time shortly after that we got a call that said:
going to give you guys a shot.

We were engaged by their firm, Alex and Justin's firm.
It's -- again, it was a year and a half ago, and I guess I could
We were basically responding to the law firm, because they were going to be the
We were making executive privilege and high-level privileges
Look, we're here to help, but you have to make those calls.
So there was a law firm that was going to make the ultimate decisionmaking on

I know we had -- I believe we had a retention with them, but it might have been

To the best of your knowledge, are you still in possession of those retainer
Like the firm wasn't responsible for payment, if that makes sense.
agreements that you signed with either Elections, LLC or MAGA PAC?
Yeah, I'm sure that they're somewhere.

Does that sound correct to you?

And then we would have been retained after that, I
we -- I'm sure we hired a lawyer to set that up and file those incorporations and do all
company was -- as those things were taking place.

Or can you give us a brief overview

We didn't know how long it was going to go,
how big it was going to go.

And that payment came from MAGA, the MAGA PAC.
as opposed to either the law firm or another entity?
I mean, I think it was probably pointed out in the

One, how large was the team?

were 30 days, but the volume of documents that we got may have driven how many

some consult -- we had our consulting team and the tech team.

So that's the physical location of 2M.
So 2M does not have a brick-and-mortar building.
sourced from people who are operating from their house.

registered in -- we may have been registered in Delaware.

When the batch of documents was

given instruction, because we weren't the ultimate decision makers.
was an organizational portion of this.

seven documents we have a question on, can we schedule a call for whatever time?

firm, and they would contact that person and say:

was the folks at NARA, and it would have been our team.

I mean, I wouldn't have -- yeah,
Let's talk about the individuals on the NARA side.

you may not recall their names but what they did, and you can provide those names later.

shout it out and I'll say that's it.
But there was one primary contact.

In an email to follow, I will give you the password.

That was pretty much the interaction with them other than when we were getting

So we did have a lot of conversations with them on the tech side.

we would need them at the ready if there was a question.

It was within a few months, I think.
Maybe in June or -- I think it was in that summer.
long after we were working on the White House stuff that that came to light.
And so then they, Cannon and -- Alex and Justin reached out and said:
here's another silo, same sort of deal.
It's NARA documents, privileges, that kind of
So we were brought into that.
And at that point, they were both -- that's about the time I think that they got
It may be that NARA was just like:
Oh, my gosh, there are millions of emails

So that's around the time that they brought Relativity in, I'm pretty sure.

Or how did that come about?
Yeah, I think that might have been that there would just be $100,000.
was like a refresh on the existing retainer.
And then as that project grew and grew, I mean, it became large.
were a lot of people working a lot of documents at some point.

I mean, we were -- well, I mean, NARA was

identifies what matter it relates to.

I have it all wrong then.

do you create a LOW file?

pages or 20,000 new documents and these are due in 7 days, these are due in 15 days,

sort of "okay, okay, I'll give you 3 more days" kind of stuff.

sometimes Laster would send me a notification and I would send it to my tech team, or

So probably more predominantly in the beginning Laster maybe went through
think they -- by and large, they come to us directly.

Now, with the payments, we see that some of the payments stop

We start seeing not round numbers.
